Expectation1: Write clean, maintainable, and efficient code
Situation1: They have a generous deadline and can refactor the module later
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They recognize the importance of being present at weekly services regularly
Story:
I stared at the lines of code on my screen, the cursor blinking in silent accusation. The module was a mess—spaghetti logic, cryptic variable names, and a tangle of quick fixes. My team lead had given me a generous deadline, trusting I’d refactor it into something clean and maintainable. I knew I could do it right if I put in the hours now, and I wanted to prove myself, to show I cared about the craft.

But Sunday was approaching, and with it, the expectation to be present at church. Not just to sit in a pew, but to worship, to connect, to serve. I’d missed a couple of services lately, telling myself I’d make up for it, but the guilt gnawed at me. My faith wasn’t just a checkbox; it was supposed to shape my life, my priorities. Yet here I was, torn between the satisfaction of a job well done and the call to be part of something bigger than myself.

The clock ticked on, and I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in, each demanding my time, my heart, my best.
